awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research:  The Impact of Digital Real Estate Technologies on Housing and Home in the US
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will investigate how the development of digital real estate technologies have affected social and economic dimensions of real estate transactions in US cities. Real estate transactions are increasingly affected by the data curated by digital real estate platforms and the algorithms underlying the presentation of data to home buyers. This digital transformation potentially affects the availability of financial instruments and the knowledge that home buyers acquire in the process of making real estate transactions. Importantly there may be differences and social justice issues relevant in how data are processed and curated for home buyers between and within cities. The objective of this research is to understand the disparate impacts of the digitalization of real estate transactions as well as the role of partnerships between city governments and the private sector in real estate markets. 
 
This research will explore how the design and use of data on web based real estate platforms creates new social and economic relationships to housing and home. This project will address whether these platforms create wider access to affordable housing, especially in terms of race and gender by drawing on concepts and theories from urban geography. The project will specifically ask how digital real estate platforms play a role in the financialization of housing, what knowledge users of digital real estate platforms acquire from these platforms and whether there are differential experiences by users from different socio-demographic groups. Interviews and focus groups with key actors in the real estate transaction process will be used to gain an understanding of the design and development of digital real estate platforms. Both archival research and participant observation will be used to additionally triangulate the findings from interviews and focus groups. Results will be disseminated to scholarly communities, through social media and through a podcast.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences
org_div_long_name: Division of Behavioral and Cognitive Sciences

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: UNIVERSITY OF KENTUCKY RESEARCH FOUNDATION, THE

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual merit

 

This project investigated how digital technologies for the management, transaction, and surveillance of real estate – collectively known as “proptech” – impact housing and home in the United States. Between May 2022 and August 2023, the co-PI collected and analyzed three kinds of data: interviews with real estate professionals and housing activists who used and/or encountered proptech, notes from attendance at proptech and real estate conferences, and archival research at the National Association of Realtors’ library in Chicago, IL. The co-PI found that practices of real estate data standardization, both historically and today, can facilitate forms of cooperative control and antitrust behavior in housing markets. The co-PI argues that by extending forms of data standardization into more granular parts of everyday life, such as dynamic rent-setting technologies and targeted underwriting software, proptech contributes to such processes of systematized thinking and cooperative control. Making sense of these changes requires paying attention to the geographies of gendered and racialized bias that have historically guided spatial data standardization within the U.S. real estate industry.

To give a concrete example, the co-PI studied the creation of the multiple listing service (MLS), a system for standardizing and exchanging spatialized real estate data among members of the National Association of Realtors (NAR). The MLS continues to serve essentially the same function that it did when it was created in the early 20th century – that is, to facilitate the exchange of information about real property among NAR members – but it increasingly takes on the characteristics of a digital platform as well. Because MLS data is widely regarded as a source of truth about housing prices, the MLS is positioned as a unique kind of mediator between Realtors who gather and manually upload information about homes and proptech firms who build derivative applications from that data. To date, the co-PI is not aware of any other studies focusing on the social dimensions of the MLS nor the role of the MLS within the proptech economy.

 

Broader impact

 

The project’s broader impact exists primarily through media appearances, conference presentations, academic journal articles currently under preparation. The co-PI was interviewed as a subject matter expert for a story about proptech and renters in South Carolina. Given that national news outlets such as The New York Times have covered developments around NAR’s anticompetitive practices in late 2023 – topics for which this award provided direct research support – the co-PI hopes to provide further insight to these public-facing conversations about the intersections between proptech, the real estate industry, and data standards. In 2022 and 2023, the co-PI presented research findings at the annual meeting of the American Association of Geographers, organizing a session on “Abolitionist Proptech” at the 2022 meeting and two paper sessions on “Spatial Histories of Real Estate Data” at the 2023 meeting. The co-PI also presented a paper focused on his findings in the National Association of Realtors’ archives at the Oxford Seminars in Cartography’s 2023 “Emerging Scholars Forum” on Artful maps and will present at the 44th annual meeting of the Society for Economic Anthropology in 2024. As a result of the award, the co-PI is drafting three academic papers – each derived from different chapters of the dissertation – for planned submission to leading journals in geography (Environment & Planning A; Annals of the AAG) and cartography (Imago Mundi), with anticipated publication dates during the 2024-2025 academic year. In August 2023, the co-PI successfully defended his dissertation and will be awarded a PhD degree.

 


Last Modified: 12/29/2023
Modified by: Ian Spangler
